{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Matt Kennon | image = Matt Kennon in June 2010.jpg | caption = Matt Kennon at BamaJam Music & Art Festival, in June 2010 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_place = | birth_date = Matthew Carl Ferguson{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/writer.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&querytype=WriterID&keyid=1002100&keyname=FERGUSON%20MATTHEW%20CARL&CAE=489722501&Affiliation=BMI|title=Search results for Ferguson, Matthew Carl|work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|accessdate=February 9, 2010}} | origin = [[Conyers, Georgia]], [[U.S.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rockdalecitizen.com/news/headlines/83736072.html|title=Local hits charts in Nashville |last=Floydd|first=Michelle|date=February 5, 2010|work=Rockdale Citizen|accessdate=February 7, 2010}} | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2001–present | label = BamaJam/[[Stroudavarious Records|Stroudavarious]] | associated_acts = [[James Stroud]], [[Randy Travis]] |website = http://mattkennon.com/ }} '''Matthew Carl Ferguson''' (born in [[Conyers, Georgia]]) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter known professionally as '''Matt Kennon'''. He has co-written a song for [[Randy Travis]] and has released one album for BamaJam Records. This album includes the top 40 hit "The Call". ==Biography== Matthew Carl Ferguson was born in [[Conyers, Georgia]]. He was adopted at birth by two parents, who had previously lost three of their four biological children to a house fire. Kennon's birth mother, who already had another son, made a decision to have an abortion, but she arrived at her doctor's office two weeks too late and was told she had to carry the child to full term.{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/01/25/matt-kennon-adoption/|title=Matt Kennon Discovers Shocking Details About His Adoption|last=Hughes|first=Donna|date=January 25, 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=September 22, 2010}} He began playing the drums at age seven, and went on to play drums in high school [[jazz]] bands.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1579734/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Matt Kennon biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=March 5, 2010}} Later on, he began performing at clubs in the [[Atlanta]], Georgia area, playing [[cover version]]s of country and [[southern rock]] songs. In the late 2000s, Kennon self-released an album of his music, which he began selling at his concerts. He then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where he met [[Travis Tritt]]'s former manager Gary Falcon, who recommended him to [[Kyle Lehning]], a record producer known for his work with [[Randy Travis]]. After Travis recorded Kennon's "Turn It Around" and released it as a single,{{cite web|url=http://www.randytravis.com/blog/italianicon235/digging-bones-xclusive-interview-matt-kennon|title=Digging Up Bones Xclusive: Interview With Matt Kennon|work=Randy Travis.com|accessdate=October 19, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818003837/http://www.randytravis.com/blog/italianicon235/digging-bones-xclusive-interview-matt-kennon|archive-date=August 18, 2009|url-status=dead}} Kennon was signed to a publishing contract. He also began working with another producer, [[James Stroud]]. Later in 2009, Kennon signed to BamaJam Records in association with [[Stroudavarious Records]] (which Stroud owns) and released his debut single "The Call,"{{cite web|url=http://www.bamajamrecords.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=100:matt-kennon-the-call&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=72|title=Matt Kennon|work=BamaJam Records|accessdate=October 19, 2009}} which he wrote with Jeremy Campbell and [[Noah Gordon (singer)|Noah Gordon]]. The song debuted at number 55 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts dated for the week of October 17, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1623560/miranda-lamberts-revolution-seizes-the-album-summit.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091021120216/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1623560/miranda-lamberts-revolution-seizes-the-album-summit.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 21, 2009|title=Miranda Lambert's ''Revolution'' seizes the album summit|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=October 10, 2009|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|accessdate=October 19, 2009}} Matt Bjorke of Roughstock gave the song a mostly-favorable review, saying that he did not enjoy the song upon first listen because of Kennon's voice, but said that the lyrics are "where it shines."{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/matt-kennon-the-call-|title=Matt Kennon — "The Call"|last=Bjorke|first=Matt|date=October 19, 2009|work=Roughstock|accessdate=October 19, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022182450/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/matt-kennon-the-call-|archive-date=October 22, 2009|url-status=dead}} Kennon's self-titled debut album was released on May 11, 2010. In advance of the album's release, he released a three-song [[extended play]] featuring "The Call" and two other songs from the album.{{cite web|url=http://musicremedy.com/m/matt-kennon/album/self-titled-8051.html|title=Matt Kennon's self titled album|date=February 11, 2010|work=Music Remedy|accessdate=February 12, 2010}} In April 2011, Kennon self-released a second album titled ''77''.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/mattkennon1|title=Matt Kennon: 77|work=[[CDBaby]]|accessdate=May 21, 2011}} In October 2012, Kennon self-released a third album titled ''Makin Music That Matters''.
